content:
= CS221 Spring 2019: Information Retrieval =
Time: !Tu/Th, 2:00- 3:20pm (Check the [https://www.reg.uci.edu/calendars/quarterly/2018-2019/quarterly18-19.html UCI Calendar] for holiday information)[[BR]]
Location: [http://www.classrooms.uci.edu/GAC/PCB1200.html PCB 1200].

|| '''Staff''' || '''Office Hours''' || '''Place''' || '''Email''' ||
|| Instructor: [http://www.ics.uci.edu/~chenli Chen Li] || Tu, 12:50 - 1:50 || DBH 2092 || chenli AT ics.uci.edu ||
|| Zuozhi Wang || Wed 1-2 || ICS 464C || zuozhiw AT uci.edu ||


== Syllabus and Lecture Notes ==
|| No. || '''Date''' || Content || '''Notes''' || '''Student Contributors''' ||
|| 01 || 4/2/19, Tu ||  Course overview || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1zltHRaV8SIfWR3DQnMFS-f2BwJ8YHFQnsYAtQ8BDP3Q/edit?usp=sharing Notes01] || ||
|| 02 || 4/4/19, Th ||  IR overview, Text processing, Tokenization, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WepWFGxiwRs Word-Breaking Video] || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1bM2REoYtXwlqbvAV4swFDRkfm5xNffy2KrTmezhOz2M/edit?usp=sharing Notes02] || Rui Guo, Shreyas Badiger Mahadev, and Sadeem Saleh ||
|| 03 || 4/9/19, Tu ||  Text processing, Tokenization, Stop words, Normalization, Stemming || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1s12ZpURT6bBwFSTI9_-lqHd2ZkOwc5OoDRNXVd2lVik/edit?usp=sharing Notes03] || Fuyao Li and Zhuang Liu ||
|| 04 || 4/11/19, Th || Text Processing, Stemming, Phrases, Character Encoding || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1GqMVpLbfQuDhVhInXHQz0z-vNubh4NDA50zIebh26Jo/edit?usp=sharing Notes04] || Xuan Liu and Ned Beigiparast ||
|| 05 || 4/16/19, Tu || Character Encoding, Inverted Indexing Overview || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/16oXJRjX3L9WLcsp7HL3c8sn7zXsxYlqb-mCYa__WFoo/edit?usp=sharing Notes05] || Zhetai Shao and Yuyang Chen ||
|| 06 || 4/18/19, Th || Inverted Indexing, LSM || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1CPWDdmsQox-gA90_-2_aZeylQB9Q8cD5QtaAmL4csWI/edit?usp=sharing Notes06] || Haixiang Yan and Hanlu Chen  ||
|| 07 || 4/23/19, Tu || [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs221-2019-spring-project2 Project 2], LSM delete || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1D6UoTgcOtNIoofgqlZUKaLnS9fFvKChxvLFTHzd3hCw/edit?usp=sharing Notes07] || Chenghao Zhang and Heming Sha ||
|| 08 || 4/25/19, Th || LSM Merge, Compression || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/12RahgHyZPDxQcnqWcyCZeSdkfM-QhYizq-G5Fgza5qc/edit?usp=sharing Notes08] || Ziyuan Cui and Zhongwei Wang ||
|| 09 || 4/30/19, Tu || Dictionary and Posting List Compression || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1BFRv3aPuXTbfdnkoDxEsGrT52-9eZ3nSwctUrQK8ODg/edit?usp=sharing Notes09] || Yang Xing and Liang Tang ||
|| 10 || 5/2/19, Th || Skip List, Boolean Model || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/12pGfJz1Hq7wjaQFYxo98ZzsV5lrfCj9Sehg4lkPbano/edit?usp=sharing Notes10] || Kaifu Jiang and Ziyang Zhang ||
|| 11 || 5/7/19, Tu || Project 2 review, [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs221-2019-spring-project3 Project 3], Positional indexing || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/12qN7ljxv5tRq0bP6iLHnvwOkxdmNjuRGiMlJ2NN96Lc/edit?usp=sharing Notes11] || Kevin Omidvaran and Mikhail Lychagin ||
|| 12 || 5/9/19, Th || Distributed Indexing and Ranked Retrieval || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1_rmA-_fjHKpNQyzKazaF8_FRVU6c11acBl5egXC1hcQ/edit?usp=sharing Notes12] || Wei-Che Chen and Meng-Hsuang Chiang ||
|| 13 || 5/14/19, Tu || !BiWords (Notes 11), Ranked Retrieval, Vector Space Model || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1Jxe81_blPxjcQB98fwHldMVwGswOh9fLDHhaquJjdtA/edit?usp=sharing Notes13] || Danni Xiong and Yidan Zhu ||
|| 14 || 5/16/19, Th || Vector Space Model, Efficient Scoring || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/113Kt4sUzRyZKLUZ2_A4DFyigZnpM63tm5GbtP40QPew/edit?usp=sharing Notes14] || Satish Kotti and Mengqi Wang ||
|| 15 || 5/21/19, Tu || IR Evaluation || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1WJ_Tmh2XIKHynBneMuRNoLpBZSGzBctIbKLtc5ypjzc/edit?usp=sharing Notes15] || Zixu Wang and Jiaren Cai ||
|| 16 || 5/22/19, Th || [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs221-2019-spring-project4 Project 4], Web Crawling || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1unq0dKLnlRup5JOFVKPQN2izDd7_T0SQJuYNQpKPddw/edit?usp=sharing Notes16] || Pritha Dawn and Nevedha Ravi ||
|| 17 || 5/27/19, Tu || !PageRank || [https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1d5eaJ9nHSVtn3W1rLBuHcxOyFUsrmXge2WI7sd2TwuE/edit?usp=sharing Notes17] || ||

Future topics (Subject to Change) :

* !PageRank, Search engine optimization
* Fuzzy Search
* Enterprise search

== Online Resources ==
 * [https://github.com/UCI-Chenli-teaching/spring19-cs221-project github repository]
 * Team signup: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_iwJOT-bnYDk9tWNNy61GCyi1kRN7s3VHdn5h_2T1DA/edit?usp=sharing Google Spreadsheet] (Use your UCI email to open the sheet) [[BR]]
 * Discussion: [https://uci-cs221-s19.slack.com/ Slack]. Invitation to Slack will be sent to your UCI email address. Here's the [wiki:cs221-2019-spring-slack-protocol protocol] for us to use Slack.  [[BR]]
 * Gradescope: Sign up on [https://www.gradescope.com/courses/46526 GradeScope] as a student using your UCI email ID. You will be added automatically.

== Projects (Subject to change) ==

We are going to develop a search engine called "Peterman", where "Peter" stands for [https://ucirvinesports.com/sports/2017/5/26/anteater-index-html.aspx Peter the Anteater]. The engine consists of several modules, and the "Document store" module is already provided by us.  Throughout the quarter you will develop the modules one by one. For each of them, we will define the API, and you are required to provide an implementation.  Each student team will also submit your own test cases to be shared with the class.

The development and submission of each module consist of three phases:

- Phase 0: Project released. We provide the API.
- Phase 1 (5 days): Students will design, write and submit at least 2 test cases. Test cases should be submitted via Github Pull Request.
- Phase 2 (3 days): Students will provide peer reviews on the submitted test cases to make sure they are all correct and have good quality. Each team should review 2 other teams' test cases and left comments under the pull requests.
- Phase 3 (before the deadline):  The goal is to pass all the test cases before submitting the project. Notice that the development of the module should start early in Phase 1 in order to have enough time finish the work before the deadline.

|| Project || Topic || Days || Weight || Test Cases Due || Review Due || Final Due Date || 
|| 1 || [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs221-2019-spring-project1 TA: Text analyzers (stemming and tokenization)] || 17 days || 19 out of 76 || Week 1 Sun. (Apr 7) || Week 2, Wed. (Apr 10) || Week 3, Wed. (Apr. 17) || 
|| 2 || [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs221-2019-spring-project2 II: Inverted index, boolean search] || 17 days || 19 out of 76 || Week 4 Tue. (Apr 23) || Week 4 Fri. (Apr 26) || Week5, Sun. (May 5) || 
|| 3 || [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs221-2019-spring-project3 PI: Positional index, phrase search] || 17 days || 19 out of 76 || Week 6 Fri. (May 10) || Week 7 Mon. (May 13) || Week 8, Wed. (May 22) || 
|| 4 || [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs221-2019-spring-project4 RA: Ranking] || 17 days || 19 out of 76 || Week 9 Tue. (May 28) || Week 9 Fri. (May 31) || Week 10, Sun. (June 9) || 


== Course Information ==

=== Overview ===
This course exposes students to principal concepts related to information retrieval, including text analyzers (e.g., stemming and tokenization), text indexing, inverted index, search (boolean expressions, phrase search), and ranking.  It will also cover topics of Web search and vertical search, with related techniques such as crawling and search engine optimization. A significant part of the course is to implement a search engine using Java.

=== Prerequisites ===

Java programming; data structures and algorithms.

=== Grading Breakdown ===
Projects: 76% [[BR]] Final: 20% (No midterm) [[BR]] Class participation: 3% [[BR]] EEE Class Evaluation: 1% [[BR]]

For all the graded projects and exams, if you disagree with the grading, you can discuss with us within '''two weeks''' after they are returned. After that, all the grades will be finalized.

=== Class participation ===

Students need to actively participate in the lectures.  Before each lecture, the instructor will come up with initial slides using Google slides.  We will assign a group of students to each lecture (except the first one) who will be responsible to keep notes during the lecture.  If needed, they can take pictures, but no photos including the lecturer please :-)  Within two days after the lecture, the assigned students will modify the initial slides and add more.  After that, the whole class, including the lecturer, will give improvement comments and suggestions within one week,  which should be taken care of by the group.  3% of the overall grade of the assigned students will be based on the quality of the final slides.

=== Textbooks ===

Introduction to Information Retrieval, Christopher D. Manning, Prabhakar Raghavan and Hinrich SchÃ¼tze, Cambridge University Press. 2008, [https://nlp.stanford.edu/IR-book/information-retrieval-book.html Book Site], [https://nlp.stanford.edu/IR-book/pdf/irbookprint.pdf PDF].

=== Using Github ===
You are required to use Github to manage your source code.  Here are the [https://grape.ics.uci.edu/wiki/public/wiki/cs221-2019-spring-project1-git instructions].

=== Working in Teams ===
Working together on projects is '''strongly encouraged'''. You need to form teams of ''2 (two)'' students and submit one project per team making sure that the names of all the team members appear on the first page. Work in teams will be graded on a per team basis.  A team of a single member needs an approval from the instructor and TA.

Students may leave their existing team in the quarter. But they cannot join any new team after the "divorce." For each team splitting, the team members should tell the instructor at least '''two weeks''' before the corresponding project/homework deadline. 

=== Project Late Policy ===
 * The official due date for each assignment is listed here on the wiki, and it is expected that students will turn the work in on or before that deadline.
 * We offer a '''24-hour grace period''' for each assignment automatically, and therefore accept submissions turned in within 24 hours of the due date, with penalty of 10 percent of the total grade of the project. For example, if a project is worth 20 points, your late project got 15 points, then you real score will be 15 - 2 = 13 points. 

 * Late assignments will NOT be accepted beyond the grace period, so do always aim to be on time! Please don't even ask, as this is what the 1-day grace period is intended for.

=== Policy on Academic Honesty ===
All students will be expected to adhere to the UCI and ICS Academic Honesty policies (see [http://www.ics.uci.edu/ugrad/policies/index.php#academic_honesty http://www.ics.uci.edu/ugrad/policies/index.php#academic_honesty] to read their details). Any student found to be involved in cheating or aiding others in doing so will be academically prosecuted to the maximum extent possible: that means you will fail this course. Just say ''no'' to cheating!
